   Assessment and Plan
   61M with HTN, untreated OSA, one month of increased tiredness, reduced
   activity tolerance and shortness of breath, eventually presenting, at
   the urging of family, with hypercarbic respiratory failure and stupor.
   NSTEMI on arrival
 now stable. Family also reported that the patient
   had been leaning to the right for a week. MRI shows diffuse disease
   including subcortical white matter and pons. PNA also likely based on
   CXR and presentation (febrile, copious secretions, no other sites of
   infection evident). The etiology of respiratory failure and low NIFs is
   still unclear, but Neurology have suggested Parsonage-[**Doctor Last Name **] brachial
   plexopathy with diaphragmatic involvement.  He has been successfully
   extubated, but was 86% on nasal [**Last Name (un) 866**] at 5 L yesterday. In view of
   target O2 of 88-92 %, successfully on nasal cannula now at 5 L and
   around 90% O2Sat.
   Brief Hospital Course (MICU)
   During the stay the patient has been switching between AC and PSV
   ventilation
 due to desynchrony with ventilator and tachypneic
   episodes.  Attempts to reduce pressure support typically resulted in
   tachypnea to the 30s-40s. Based on bicarbonate at admission, his ppCO2
   at baseline is likely 20 mmHg above the normal range or 55-65 mmHg.
   The etiology of his decompensation is unclear, but it is important to
   note that he suffers from untreated OSA, about 120 pack-year history of
   smoking, HTN, polycythemia (perhaps due to chronic hypoxia or maybe
   primary), PNA and apparently abnormal respiratory drive
 in response
   to hypoxia or reduced pressure support he becomes tachypneic with low
   tidal volumes.  In addition to this, he may have had some diaphragmatic
   weakness. Based on previous echo he does not have pulmonary
   hypertension and only has a trace of heart failure on clinical exam
   without much improvement of breathing after diuresis.  Last NIF while
   intubated was
 26 cm H2O. We have decided not to repeat this. An
   inspiratory/expiratory CXR was ordered but the patient did not perform
   the needed respiratory maneuvers. We decided not to repeat because his
   other chest x-rays have been quite nice inspiratory films, suggesting
   that if the diaphragm is weak, we may not see it this way. PNA was
   quite possible based on thick secretions, cough, but CXRs are now clear
   and sputum examination has not been fruitful.
   Today he is comfortable, although weak (likely from extended
   prostration), on nasal cannula at 5L. We think that COPD has been a
   likely contributor in addition to the above, despite relatively
   unimpressive emphysema on CT.
   Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure/Pneumonia
   Breathing is improved. Although still requiring supplemental O2 he is
   now extubated and comfortable on nasal cannula. Likely smoking-related
   lung injury and known OSA, possible PNA contributing, now completed
   ceftriaxone and levo. No meaningful improvement with lasix so far
   although has corrected volume status. Neurology have suggested that a
   weakened diaphragm from Parsonage-[**Doctor Last Name **] brachial plexopathy as a
   possible contributor but effectively ruled-out neuromuscular causes
   including myasthenia [**Last Name (un) **], ALS, Guillian-[**Location (un) **] and thinking other
   causes unlikely.
   - Permissive CO2 around 58-62 mmHg and O2 88-92%
   - Stop nebs, but start Advair, albuterol for likely COPD
   - Continue nasal cannula for now
   OSA
   Treated with autoset CPAP last night.  This should continue with
   education and continuance at home.
   - Continue pressure support with mask at night.
   - Sleep Medicine outpatient follow-up (recommend in DC summary given
   lives in [**State 3421**])
   - PFTs and DLCO as outpatient after recovery from acute event (as
   above)
   Transaminitis
   Likely statin related. Low dose statin restarted. Not a complete
   contraindication, therefore on lower dose (which can still be of
   benefit)
   - Statin 10 mg (80 mg started on admission)
   - Follow
   Fever
   No fever now; No positive cultures nor other obvious site of infection.
   Unlikely VAP.
   - Follow cultures but no more for now
   - CXR depending on exam findings
   Lethargy/altered mental status
   Has resolved with weaning of sedation. [**Month (only) 51**] have been purely secondary
   to respiratory failure. Good to keep in mind unlikely contribution of
   brainstem Binswanger disease but presentation somewhat indolent.
   Nonetheless may make patient more sensitive to anesthetic.
   Rash
   Resolved. Unclear if drug reaction (is similar to drug rash) or,
   perhaps less likely, viral exanthem. [**Doctor Last Name 121**] responsible not clear.
   Elevated troponin/ECG changes
   NSTEMI stable on ASA, BB (adjust as tolerated), statin. Cardiology
   following.  Consider ACEI on discharge.
   - Increase metoprolol to 50 TID
   - Statin (10mg) and ASA (81 mg)
   - Consider ACEI/Ca channel antagonist if needed subsequently
   - Follow-up with cardiology as outpatient
   Polycythemia
   Stable
 likely related to COPD/OSA. Will follow.
   Constipation
   Resolved and in fact stool was loose.
   - Continue colace/senna
   ICU care

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with hypercarbic respiratory failure, reduced level of consciousness, and NSTEMI. He has a history of hypertension, untreated OSA, and chronic smoking. He was initially intubated and mechanically ventilated, but was successfully extubated and is now on nasal cannula at 5L with an O2 saturation of 90%. He has been diagnosed with pneumonia, likely secondary to COPD and OSA, and is being treated with antibiotics and bronchodilators. He also has polycythemia, likely related to COPD and OSA, and is being monitored.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's hypercarbic respiratory failure may worsen if he is not properly managed, leading to further respiratory distress and potential respiratory arrest.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia may progress and spread to other parts of the lungs, leading to worsening respiratory failure and potentially life-threatening complications.
3. Cardiac Complications: The patient's NSTEMI may lead to further cardiac complications, such as heart failure, arrhythmias, or even cardiac arrest.
4. Neurological Complications: The patient's neurological status may deteriorate further if he is not properly managed, leading to increased risk of neurological complications, such as stroke or seizures.
5. Infection: The patient's pneumonia and other potential infections may lead to sepsis, which can be life-threatening if not properly managed.
6. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's hypertension and polycythemia may increase his risk of cardiovascular complications, such as heart failure, arrhythmias, or cardiac arrest.
7. Respiratory Distress: The patient's respiratory distress may worsen if he is not properly managed, leading to further respiratory failure and potentially life-threatening complications.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition is stable, but he requires continued close monitoring and management. He will be continued on nasal cannula with O2 saturation of 90% and will receive antibiotics and bronchodilators for his pneumonia. He will also be monitored for potential cardiac complications and will be treated with ASA, BB, and statin for his NSTEMI. His polycythemia will be monitored and managed as necessary. He will be discharged to rehabilitation once his condition stabilizes and he is no longer requiring mechanical ventilation.

Based on the patient's daily progress note, here is a summary of the information and potential medical complications that can arise:

**Patient Summary:**

The patient is a 61-year-old male with a history of hypertension, untreated obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), and a 120-pack-year history of smoking. He was admitted with hypercarbic respiratory failure, reduced level of consciousness, and NSTEMI. He has been treated with antibiotics and has shown improvement in his respiratory status, but still requires supplemental oxygen.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Respiratory Failure:** The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to a combination of factors, including untreated OSA, smoking-related lung injury, and possible pneumonia. He may require continued respiratory support, including CPAP and oxygen therapy.
2. **Pneumonia:** The patient's pneumonia is likely caused by a bacterial infection, and he has been treated with antibiotics. However, the infection may not have fully resolved, and further treatment may be necessary.
3. **NSTEMI:** The patient's NSTEMI is stable, and he has been treated with aspirin, beta-blockers, and statins. However, he may require continued cardiac care and monitoring.
4. **Parsonage-Turner Syndrome:** The patient's symptoms are consistent with Parsonage-Turner Syndrome, a rare condition that causes weakness or paralysis of the diaphragm. This may contribute to his respiratory failure and require further evaluation and treatment.
5. **Polycythemia:** The patient's polycythemia is likely related to his COPD and OSA. He may require continued monitoring and treatment to manage this condition.
6. **Constipation:** The patient's constipation has resolved, but he may require continued treatment with laxatives to prevent recurrence.
7. **Transaminitis:** The patient's transaminitis is likely caused by statins or propofol. He has been treated with statins, and his liver function tests are trending down.
8. **Fever:** The patient's fever is likely related to his pneumonia or other underlying conditions. He may require further evaluation and treatment to manage his fever.
9. **Lethargy/Altered Mental Status:** The patient's lethargy and altered mental status may be related to his respiratory failure or other underlying conditions. He may require further evaluation and treatment to manage these symptoms.
10. **Rash:** The patient's rash has resolved, but he may require further evaluation to determine the cause of the rash.

**Assessment and Plan:**

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the assessment is that he is stable but still requires continued respiratory support and monitoring. The plan is to continue CPAP and oxygen therapy, as well as antibiotics for his pneumonia. He will also require continued cardiac care and monitoring, as well as management of his polycythemia and constipation. Further evaluation and treatment may be necessary to manage his Parsonage-Turner Syndrome, transaminitis, fever, lethargy/altered mental status, and rash.
